title: Isimud
text:
Isimud (also Isinu; Usmû; Usumu (<a href="Akkadian%20language">Akkadian</a>)) is a minor <a href="deity">god</a>, the <a href="sukkal">sukkal</a> of the god <a href="Enki">Enki</a>, in <a href="Mesopotamian%20mythology">Sumerian mythology</a>.
In ancient Sumerian artwork, Isimud is easily identifiable because he is always depicted with two faces facing in opposite directions in a way that is similar to the ancient Roman god <a href="Janus">Janus</a>.
Mythology.
Isimud appears in the legend of "Inanna and Enki", in which he is the one who greets Inanna upon her arrival to the E-Abzu temple in <a href="Eridu">Eridu</a>. He also is the one who informs Enki that the "<a href="Me%20%28mythology%29">mes</a>" have been stolen. In the myth, Isimud also serves as a messenger, telling Inanna to return the "mes" to Enki or face the consequences. Isimud plays a similar role to <a href="Ninshubur">Ninshubur</a>, Inanna's "sukkal". Isimud also appears in the myth of "Enki and <a href="Ninhursag">Ninhursag</a>", in which he acts as Enki's messenger and emissary.
